headline: GALLEY SENTENCED TO LIFE FOR MURDERS AT MYLAI 4; LENGTHY REVIEW TO BEGIN
lead_paragraph: FORT BENNING, Ga., March 31—First Lieut. William L. Cal ley Jr. was sentenced to life imprisonment today for slaying at least 22 South Vietnamese civilians three years ago at the hamlet of Mylai 4.
author: By Romer Bigart Special to The New York Times

headline: Reports by Saigon on Toll Inflicted on Enemy in Laos Are Arousing Doubts
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31 — The campaign against Communist supply lines in Laos is over, but statistical warfare continues to rage, rem iniscent of the days when American commanders put the stress on “the body count” to demonstrate success in the Viet nam war.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Verdict Protested Anew; 3 Try to Jail Themselves
lead_paragraph: The outcome of the trial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. stirred renewed and mount ing protests yesterday, with many Americans expressing their feelings through tele grams, petitions and resolu tions, and a few—both public figures and private citizens — taking more dramatic action.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: White House Reaction
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., March 31 (AP) — At the West ern White House, the press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said the regulation “seems to be directed towards support of the President and his Vietnam policy.” Asked by reporters if Mr. Nixon agreed that United States involvement in the war should be ended by January, 1973, Mr. Ziegler said. “It's our objective to accomplish these objectives as soon as possible.”

headline: Doc Blanchard Retires
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex., March 31 (AP) — Col. Felix (Doc) Blanchard, all‐America fullback at Army in 1944‐46, retired from the Air Force yesterday. Blanchard flew 113 jet fighter missions in the Vietnam War.

headline: Thieu Terms Laos Drive Saigon's ‘Biggest Victory’
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31—President Nguyen Van Thieu declared today that his troops' recent thrust into Laos had attained “the biggest victory ever” for the armedforces of South Vietnam.

headline: Hard Labor Defined
lead_paragraph: FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 31 (UPI)—Maj. Cleve Cunningham, public informa tion officer at Fort Leaven worth, said tonight that the “hard labor” Lieutenant Calley was sentenced to “happens to be only a term.”

headline: New Effort Against Trail
lead_paragraph: DONGHA, South Vietnam, March 31 — A “new phase” in the South Vietnamese effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was announced here today by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

headline: CASUALTIES HEAVY AS ENEMY BURNS TOWN IN VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 1 — Enemy troops have attacked and burned most of a district capital in the northern part of South Vietnam, reportedly inflicting heavy casualties on civilians and their militia.

headline: Thieu Comments He Was Confident Guilty Would Pay
lead_paragraph: DONG HA, South Vietnam, March 31 — President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that he had been confident that justice would punish those guilty of the killings at Mylai.

headline: NEW DRIVE BEGINS IN AREA OF MYLAI
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 31—South Vietnamese troops have begun a sweeping operation in the general region where the Mylai massacre oc curred three years ago that may force as many as 16,000 people from their homes.
author: By Henry Kamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Liberals Seek ‘War Crimes’ Inquiry
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 — With the aid of some Vietnam veterans, a group of liberal Democrats sought today to pre vail upon the House Armed Services Committee to conduct a public inquiry into alleged American war crimes in Viet nam.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ASK PULLOUT BY '73
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 — House Democrats called today for an end to United States involvement in Indochina by the start of 1973.
author: By Marjorie Hunter Special to The New York Times

headline: Chinese Fishing Boat Sunk In Collision With Soviet Ship
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31 — The Soviet Union announced tonight that a Soviet freighter had col lided with and sunk a Commun ist Chinese fishing schooner in the Gulf of Tonkin off the North Vietnam coast last night.

headline: Life for Lieutenant Calley
lead_paragraph: The military court that ruled against unnecessary barbarism in war in convicting Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of murder in Vietnam was wisely consistent in rejecting the barbarism of capital punishment when it sentenced the young officer to life imprisonment.

headline: Agnew Describes Fulbright As Arrogant and Frustrated
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI)—Vice President Agnew today described Senator J. Wil liam Fulbright as an arrogant, frustrated presidential candi date who was currying favor with the news media and feed ing Hanoi's hope for a divided United States.

headline: Pravda Scores Pentagon
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31 — The Communist party newspaper, Pravda, charged today that Lieutenant Calley was a “scape goat” and that his trial had been part of “a whole series of ma chinations by the Pentagon to save from justice most of those involved in the crime.”

headline: Kremlin Rules Out Easing Of Bars to Western Ideas
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, March 31—Rank ing Soviet Communist party, leaders lashed out at Moscow's ideological adversaries today and told the party's 24th Con gress that there should be no letup in resistance to ideas not approved by the Kremlin.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Bans Weeklies Again
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)—Saigon authori ties have banned the April 4 issues of Time and Newsweek from sale in South Vietnam for articles considered “hostile to national security.” It marked the second week in a row that the magazines have been banned here. The action does not affect sales to American military personnel in post ex changes.

headline: U.S. Veterans of Vietnam War Rally on Wall Street for Peace
lead_paragraph: A veteran of the war in Vietnam who has three Purple Hearts, a Bronze Star and a Silver Star told a noontime Wall Street rally yesterday, “We are all of us in this country guilty for having allowed the war to go on.”

headline: 400 College Leaders Condemn War Policy in Letter to Nixon
lead_paragraph: More than 400 student presi dents and college editors have signed an open letter to Presi dent Nixon condemning his policies in Vietnam and charg ing that the Administration “seriously misinterprets the mood of both the campus and the countryside.”
author: By John Kifner

headline: Agnew Denounces ‘Home‐Front Snipers’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1— Vice President Agnew called critics of the war in Indochina “home‐front snipers!” today and accused them of having fos tered a negative attitude to ward American combat vet erans.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: The ‘Forgotten’ G.I.'s Near Khesanh
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 30—The American in fantrymen who have been patrolling the jungle‐covered mountains west of Khesanh —fighting and sometimes dy ing in obscure small‐unit clashes while supporting the South Vietnamese invasion of Laos—feel that they are for gotten men.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: F.B.I. CHECKED GROUP RELAYING P.O.W. MAIL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) —The Federal Bureau of Inves tigation confirmed today that it had questioned relatives of prisoners of war about the peace group that relays mail to and from American prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

headline: DRAFT UNTIL 1973 IS VOTED BY HOUSE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — The House voted overwhelming ly tonight to continue the mili tary draft until the middle of 1973 and sharply increase pay and allowances for servicemen.
author: By David E. Rosenbaum Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As the South Vietnamese stream back across the border, the official dispatches‐7‐and President Nixon him self—describe the military action in Laos as successful.
author: Saul Levitt

headline: Opposition to Galley's Conviction and Sentence Grows in Nation
lead_paragraph: With telegrams, offers of money and demonstrations, Americans in both the public and private sectors expressed growing opposition yesterday to the conviction and sentenc ing of First‐Lieut. William L Calley Jr.

headline: Recapture of Base. Overrun by Enemy Reported by Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, April 2—A two‐day battle in the Central Highlands in which a North Vietnamese regi ment stormed into a South, Vietnamese fire base and then was pushed out again was re ported today by the Saigon command.

headline: New Phase of Indochina Debate
lead_paragraph: News Analysis
author: By Max Frankel Special to The New York Times

headline: Foe Recaptures Laos Post
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 1 (Reuters) — North Vietnamese forces launched a heavy coun terattack around the royal cap ital of Luang Prabang in north ern Laos and recaptured a stra tegic hilltop position, a De fense Ministry spokesman said today.

headline: PRESIDENT ORDERS GALLEY RELEASED FROM STOCKADE
lead_paragraph: President Nixon yesterday ordered First Lieutenant Wil liam L. Calley Jr. released from the stockade at Fort Benning, Ga., and returned to his guar ters on the base while his mur der conviction is being re viewed.
author: By Linda Charlton

headline: Dissidence Unit Has Dossier on 14,000
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — A Department of Justice intel ligence unit that has replaced an Army Intelligence detach ment as the Government's main watchman of political dis sidence has compiled computer ized dossiers on nearly 14,000 Americans.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Georgians in House Shift To Opposition to the War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1—A break appeared today in the once solid Southern flank in the House supporting the Viet nam war as two conservative Democrats from Georgia ani flounced their opposition to continuation of the fighting.
author: By Join W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Critics of U.S. Oil Policies in Vietnam Shift Focus of Their Attacks
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 1 — Critics of the Nixon Adminis tration's oil policies In South Vietnam are shifting the focus of their attacks.
author: By Philip Shabecoff Special to The New York Times

headline: Week's U.S. War Toll: 58 Dead, 542 Wounded
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 1 (AP)—The United States command reported to day that 58 Americans were killed in combat last week and 542 were wounded. It was the highest American death toll in a month and the Iargest number of wounded in six months.

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: For millions of Americans, the Calley verdict has raised terrible questions about the responsibility for things that have happened it Indochina in the last six years. It is right and inevitable that we examine that record of the past. But it is more urgent that we face one simple fact about the present:
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Americans Closing The Support Bases Used in Laos Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, April 3 (AP)—Long lines of helicopters flew southward out of Quangtri in northeastern South Vietnam yesterday as the United States was closing down its support role for the recent South Vietnamese thrust into Laos.

headline: Marine Serves a Year In 12 Vietnam Killings
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., April 2 (UPI)—Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz of Weirton, W. Va., convicted of murder ing 12 Vietnamese women and children near Danang in February, 1970, was released today from the Portsmouth naval prison.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Hugh B. Hester

headline: White House Mail
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 2 (UPI)—The Western White House said today that tele grams continued to pour in at a rate of 100 to 1 favoking clemency for Lieutenant Caney.

headline: Trial Is Defended by Army
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2—The Army, defending itself against public outcry against the trial and conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., said to day that it had “a moral and legal obligation” to prosecute him.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: Mail on Calley, Especially From South, Takes on Emotional Tone
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 — One Californian protested with poetry in a letter: “A single leaf does not turn yellow without the silent knowledge of the whole tree.”

headline: HEARINGS START ON A MYLAI CASE
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., April 2 —Preliminary hearings opened here today in the court‐mar tial of Col. Oran K. Henderson, the fourth and highest ranking Army man to be tried on charges arising from the killing of civilians at Mylai 4 almost three years ago.
author: By Emanuel Perlmutter

headline: G.O.P. Antiwar Letter
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) —Fast‐spreading sentiment in Congress for ending the Viet nam war received new impetus today as five House Republi cans joined the effort to pull out all American troops by the end of the year.

headline: DECISION BY NIXON ON CALLEY HAILED
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's order re leasing First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. from the stockade pending a review of his case continued to receive widespread public and private support yes terday.
author: By John Darnton

headline: Gov. Wallace Sees Galley;
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 2 — First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., now confined to a tiny apartment while his conviction for murder is appealed, spent his first day out of the Fort Benning stockade greeting a parade of visitors that included Gov. George C. Wallace.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: Woman's Peace Walk Is Over After 45 Days and 450 Miles
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 2 — Looking weary but smiling broadly, Mrs. Louise Bruyn walked up the white marble steps of the Capitol at noon today, ending a 450‐mile peace walk that she began 45 days ago in her home town of New ton, Mass.

headline: WESTMORELAND SAYS HE HARBORS NO GUILT
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, April 2 (AP)— The Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who was the commander of Ameri can troops In Vietnam at the time of the Mylai slayings, said here today that he was sur prised at the outcry following the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley.

headline: Antiwar Editor Plans Trip To Vietnam on Mail Seizure
lead_paragraph: The editor of an antiwar newspaper for servicemen said yesterday that, he would go to Vietnam to investigate the ef fect of an Army directive con fiscating antiwar literature ad dressed to soldiers in Vietnam.

headline: School Integration Is Termed Harmful To Blacks in South
lead_paragraph: A leader of the Southern Christian Leadership Confer ence told a rally at City Hall Park yesterday that black peo ple in the South would be “better off” with school segre gation.

headline: YALE PARLEY HELD ON ANTIWAR ADS
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN, April 3—Two hundred advertising people from New York gathered at Yale University today to dis cuss strategy on “unselling” the war in Indochina to the American people.
author: By Steven R. Weisman Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘Who Could Conceive of This?’ Asks Army Doctor at Khesanh
lead_paragraph: KHESANH, South Vietnam, March 20 — The 29‐year‐old Army doctor, who has been treating wounded Americans here for 49 days, recalled with dread the time when a G.I. asked him a question.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: CLASH AT TEACH‐IN UPSETS HARVARD
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 3 —Since the disruption of a pro war teach‐in on March 26, Har vard University administrators have been meeting almost con tinuously with students to ex press their concern over the need to protect free speech.

headline: Officials at Fort Benning Silent On New Calley Move by Nixon
lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ga., April 3— While First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. settled into the clois tered routine of his semi‐seques tered life, United States Army officials here at Fort Benning remained silent today on Presi dent Nixon's decision to make a final review of the Lieuten ant's court‐martial conviction for murder.
author: By James T. Wooten Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: They marched First Lieut. Wil liam Laws Calley Jr. to the stock ade at Fort Benning, Ga., last week. The longest court‐martial in military history had ended, and Calley stood convicted and sentenced to life in prison for the premeditated murder of not fewer than 22 unarmed, un resisting Vietnamese men, wo men and children at Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968.
author: —Richard Hammer

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.—The pressures of politics and war seem remote on this lovely stretch of California coastline, but last week there was no earthly way to avoid them. Mr. Nixon had come here 10 days ago to rest and sort out his thoughts before his television ad dress on Vietnam this Wednes day night. Yet, the world would not let him alone and he seemed, suddenly, a President under siege.
author: —Robert B. Semple Jr

headline: BUILD‐UP AT DMZ BY FOE REPORTED
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3 — Intelligence reports reaching Washington indicate a continu ing North Vietnamese build‐up north of the demilitarized zone and new enemy troop move ments in Laos, Cambodia and the northern part of South Vietnam.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: WASHINGTON
lead_paragraph: FIERY RUN, Va., April 3—For a while it almost looked as if somebody were going to propose giving Lieuten ant Calley the Congressional Medal of Honor. Not since the firing of Gen. Dougias MacArthur during the Korean war has there been such an outburst of sympathy for an American soldier. So at last Vietnam has produced an officer everybody recognizes—an anti hero for a war without glory or no bility and a symbol for a time of moral confusion.
author: By James Reston

headline: NIXON DECLARES HE WILL REVIEW THE CALLEY CASE
lead_paragraph: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., April 3—The White House announced today that President Nixon would personally review and decide the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. “before any final sentence is carried out.”
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Wounded G.L.'s Bitter Over Calley Conviction
lead_paragraph: At the Memphis Veterans Hospital, where many Viet nam veterans are being cared for, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. last week was greeted with expressions of deep bitter ness.

headline: Ex‐Beret Says He Killed Agent on Orders of C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Marasco, one of the eight Green Berets who were charged but never tried in the slaying two years ago of a South Vietnamese suspected to have been a double agent, says that he shot and killed the man on “oblique yet very, very clear orderes” from the Central Intelli gence Agency.
author: By John Darnton

headline: ENEMY ATTACKS BASE FOR 4TH DAY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, April 4 —Military, spokesmen reported today Vila South Vietnamese troops re pulsed another fierce attack yesterday on a small fire base in the Central Highlands near the Laotian border.

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: SAIGON—One objective of the 45‐day allied operation against the Ho Chi Minh Trail network in Laos was to prevent a Com munist offensive in the northern regions of South Vietnam. But last week, only a few days after the operation ended, North. Viet namese and Vietcong forces struck in a series of attacks that were more costly in Amer ican and South Vietnamese lives than any in the area since last summer.

headline: Marine Out of Prison For Vietnam Slayings
lead_paragraph: WEIRTON, W. Va., April 3 (AP) — Michael Schwarz, home after a 10‐month prison term for the murder of 12 South Vietnamese civilians, celebrated a belated Christ mas with his family today while telling of hopes to re turn to Vietnam.

headline: Rabbis' Group Urges Pullout In Vietnam by Year's End
lead_paragraph: The Central Conference of American Rabbis called on President Nixon yesterday to withdraw all American mili tary forces from Vietnam by the end of this year.

headline: Gallup Finds 79% Disapprove of Verdict
lead_paragraph: The overwhelming majority of Americans—79 per cent— disapprove of the court‐mar tial finding that First Lieut. William L. Calley was guilty of the premeditated murder of at least 22 South Vietnam ese at Mylai in 1968, accord ing to the Gallup Poll.

headline: Calley Verdict Brings Home the Anguish of War to Public
lead_paragraph: In cities and towns across the nation, to a people who have lived secure in homes and shops and factories untouched by the roaring guns and bombs of modern warfare, the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. of the United States Army seems clearly to have brought home a sense of the anguish of war.

headline: The President and Mylai
lead_paragraph: No development in the whole tragic history of the Vietnam war has produced a more spontaneous outcry than, the conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. The protests have brought into unaccustomed unity such divergent national figures as Gov. George C. Wallace Alabama and Dr. Benjamin Speck, to say nothing millions of Americans not normally given to public expressions of outrage.

headline: ‘No Comment,’ Says C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 3—The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it had no corn. ment to make concerning Mr. Marasco's statement.

headline: NOTRE DAME PRIZE GOES TO KUNSTLER
lead_paragraph: NOTRE DAME, Ind., April 3 —William M. Kunstler accepted last night the 1971 Senior Fel low Award of the University lof Notre Dame with a call to “end the war now—by what ever means necessary, short of violence to human beings.”

headline: Curfew Changed in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 3 (Reuters)—Curfew hours for American servicemen in Saigon have been readjusted to conform with the existing Vietnamese curfew. The new hours of curfew are from 1 A.M. to 5:30 A.M. local time in stead of from 10 P.M. to 6 A.M.

headline: COOPER AND CHURCH PLAN NEW MEASURE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) —A new Cooper‐Church amend ment is planned and it will ask President Nixon to set a date for total withdrawal of all United States forces from South Vietnam, its authors said today.

headline: Rookie Wins Greensboro Golf Playoff
lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4—Brian (Bud) Allin, a 26‐year‐ old red‐haired rookie, crashed through to success in big league golf today when he won the Greater Greensboro open at the first extra hole of a sudden‐death playoff. Sinking a 32‐foot birdie putt, the former Army lieutenant, who served 18 months in Vietnam, beat Dave Eichelberger and Rod Funseth after all three had tied with 72‐hole totals of 275 at the Sedgefield Country Club.
author: By Lincoln A. Werden Special to The New York Times

headline: Cambodians Withdraw
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Mon day, April 5 (Reuters)—A mili tary spokesman said today that North Vietnamese regulars be gan a series of attacks last night and forced Cambodian troops to withdraw from posi tions on the eastern bank of the Mekong River.

headline: Sunday in Saigon: A Lazy Festivity
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4—This Sunday in Sai gon started for some today with antiwar songs and a party in a dimly lit cafe and ended for others with Gabriel Faure's Requiem in the Ro man Catholic Cathedral and a Chinese opera on television. In between, most people passed the day trying with varying degrees of success to forget the Laotian operation, the rest of the war, politics and high prices.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Gen. Maxwell Taylor writes [Op‐Ed March 10]: “Since our involvement in Vietnam there have been only three strategic alternatives from which to choose—ito advance, to retreat or to stand fast.”
author: NEWBOLD MORRIS Teton Village, Wyo., March 15, 1971

headline: A Pacification Adviser Charges Corruption
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 — United States offi cials are disturbed by a lack of information from American ad visers in the field concerning the real status of pacification in South Vietnam.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Enemy Raids Cast Doubt on Claims of Success in Laos
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 4 —Professional American and South Vietnamese soldiers who have assessed favorably the re cent operations in Laos have been unpleasantly surprised by the last week's heavy enemy at tacks in South Vietnam.
author: By Craig It. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Hughes to Propose Panel To Fix War Crimes Blame
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4 (UPI) —Senator Harold E. Hughes said today that he would pro pose the creation of an interna tional commission of leading jurists to set standards for as sessing blame when innocent civilians are killed in a war.

headline: The Cry of America
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The, trial of William Calley is over; now is the trial of the nation. The camera swings from the impassive face of the man who pre sided over the death of some 22 civil ians. Now the glaring light rests upon the people in whose name and by whose power many thousand times that number have died in distant Asia. If at the court‐martial the agony pierced the Army, and one of its young lieutenants, now it is ours.
author: By Francis B. Sayre Jr

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: In the Johnson Administration, peo ple used to talk about “the nun gap” as a necessity in getting the United States out of Vietnam. By that they meant that there had to be a reason able period of time between the American exit and the first Communist attack on a nun—in other words, the collapse of the anti‐Communist Gov ernment in Saigon.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: U.S. Finds Soviet Speeches Cautious
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 4—Sen ior officials of the Nixon admin istration regard United States Soviet relations as in an “in determinate state” in which minor irritants often tend to overshadow major political issues.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: Appellate Court Backs N.Y.U. On Closing in 1970 Disorders
lead_paragraph: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that New York University need not refund tui tion for 19 days of classes can celed last May during student disorders over the invasion of Cambodia.
author: By Robert D. McFadden

headline: 608 Copters Reported Damaged
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 4 (UPI)— Enemy gunners damaged 608 United States helicopters dur ing the six‐week Laos offen sive, shooting down 104 of them, Lieut. Gen. Hoang Xuan Lam told South Vietnam's Sen ate Defense Committee in a report made available today.

headline: Vietnam Peasants Return to a Hamlet, Hungry and Bitter Toward Regime
lead_paragraph: PHUQUI, South Vietnam—The peasants of this hamlet have returned home two years after having been forced from their huts during an American military sweep, but their lives are, disrupted and many are bitter and hostile toward the Government.

headline: Foe Bolsters Force In Laos
lead_paragraph: VIENTIANE, Laos, April 5 Reuters)—A Laotian Defense Ministry spokesman said today that the North Vietnamese were reinforcing their position around the royal Laotian capital of Luang Prabang and bringing in antiaircraft guns.

headline: Trail Raided Again
lead_paragraph: QVANGTRI, Thursday, April 6 (Reuters)—South Vietnamese commandos staged another raid today against the Ho Chi Minh trail in southern Laos.

headline: VIETNAMESE POST FIGHTS OFF WAVES OF ENEMY TROOPS
lead_paragraph: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 6 — A South Vietnamese artillery base near the Laotian border was reported under heavy shelling yesterday after having withstood waves of North Vietnamese ground attacks the day before.

headline: CONGRESS DIVIDED OVER CALLEY CASE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5 (UPI) — Members of Congress, crossing party lines, split sharply today over the case of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. and President Nixon's plan to make the final decision on his punishment.

headline: The Consequences of Laos
lead_paragraph: President Nixon undoubtedly is tempted to accent the positive as he draws up a new balance sheet on the Laotian invasion for his report to the nation tomorrow on further American troop withdrawals. Public optimism about the outlook in Vietnam has always been felt necessary by the Administration to justify the troop rundown, which Mr. Nixon has committed himself to continue at the current rate of 12,500 a month or faster.

headline: Senators Tale Opener;
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—The Washington Senators won their opening‐day game today for the first time in nine years—an event of no small importance in this somewhat dispirited town.
author: By Edwin L. Dale Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Now Down to 300,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 5 (AP)—The United States Command announced today a reduction of 4,600 American troops in South Vietnam, dropping the total number to 301,900, as of last Thursday, the lowest since late summer, 1966.

headline: Convicted Marine Waits
lead_paragraph: QUANTICO, Va., April 5 (UPI)—Marine Pvt. Michael A. Schwarz, convicted a year ago of murdering 12 Vietnamese women and children, reported for duty at Marine Corps schools here today to await “some kind of discharge” or a review of his appeal. Private Schwarz was sentenced to life imprisonment by a court‐martial in Vietnam, but the sentence was later reduced to one year, a dishonorable discharge and loss of payment and allowances. He was released last Friday from naval prison.

headline: Abernathy Leads Protest on Wall St.
lead_paragraph: About 4,000 demonstrators stood for nearly two hours in the chilling shade of Wall Street yesterday afternoon to take part in the opening of the “spring offensive against repression.”
author: By James F. Clarity

headline: 92 IN CAPITAL HELD IN ANTIWAR RALLY
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—The District of Columbia police arrested 92 antiwar demonstrators, most of them young seminarians, near the White House today.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: 2 Saigon Senators Say Minh Could Win
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—Two South Vietnamese opposition senators predicted today that Gen. Duong Van Minh could win next October's presidential elections if the voting was free and honest.
author: By Tad Szulc Special to The New York Times

headline: McCloskey's Challenge
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 5—‐Representative Paul “Pete” McCloskey Jr., the California Republican who has raised the flag of rebellion within the G.O.P. against President Nixon's war policy, leaves today for Vietnam. Asked why he is going, he replies, with quiet intensity, “to get the facts.”
author: By William V. Shannon

headline: Foreign Press Criticizes Nixon's Decision on Galley
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 5—In many countries friendly to the United States there has been a highly critical reaction to President Nixon's intervention in the Calley case.
author: By Anthony Lewis Special to The New York Times

headline: How to End the War Now
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam—The invasions of Laos and Cambodia are no solution for the people of Indochina. Nor is. Vietnamlzation. The Nixon plan to “end” the war fails to take into consideration that a negotiated political compromise is the only way to peace.
author: By Don Luce

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is probably correct to conclude that the prosecution and conviction of Lieutenant Calley are consistent with the broad principles laid down at the Nuremberg Trials. But it does seem to me very important to bear in mind that the accused persons at Nuremberg were not the Lieutenant. Calleys. They were rather among the most responsible policy makers in Hitler's Germany.

headline: Ammunition Abandoned

headline: A War Distorted
lead_paragraph: Whatever was to happen to William Calley, one result of the first Mylai trial was certain in advance: the United States Army was going to be found Guilty. The Army couldn't win. If Calley had been let off: a whitewash. If he had been (as he has been) condemned: a scapegoat for the higher brass. That's the way the media set it up and, in the courtrooms of our global village, the media, as we all know, are prosecutor, judge and jury.
author: By James Burnham

headline: Washington Notes
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8—Pentagon generals and admirals, expert at feint and flank attack, have demonstrated in a series of bureaucratic skirmishes that they do not intend to be dominated by President Nixon's fledgling Office of Management and Budget Not all the details have emerged, but in the most Portentous clash the Joint Chiefs of Staff executed a successful maneuver around the office's director, George P. headline: Mr. Nixon's Vietnam Politics
lead_paragraph: President Nixon's latest restatement of his Vietnam policy is essentially a political document, taking into account the present state of American politics, the impending peace demonstrations in Washington, rising antiwar sentiment in the Congress, the Calley outcry and the approaching Presidential campaign. These factors were undoubtedly a prime consideration in leading him now to a commitment to end totally the American military involvement in Vietnam by a date that, though unstated, can hardly be much later than Election Day in November 1972.

headline: Behind the Protests
lead_paragraph: The United States is fighting a war in Vietnam. It has come to pass that in modern warfare deliberately inflicted civilian casualties are taken for granted. Nonetheless, Gen. William C. Westmoreland, Chief of Staff, assures us, “It was clearly known to our troops that they were to avoid civilian casualties at all costs.” Atrocities were to be reported and punished accorded to the rules of the Geneva Convention. General Westmoreland admits that many civilians have been killers in Vietnam; but to allege that any responsibility or guilt rests in the high command is, according to him, “absurd.” He places the responsibility on troops “led by inexperienced lieutenants and sergeants,” who are being tried.

headline: Vietnamize At Home
lead_paragraph: Now that the Vietnamization of the war is under way in Vietnam, it's time to end the Vietnamization of our political system at home. This domestic Vietnamization—the draft, the attitude toward dissent, the ubiquitous secret agents—has driven an entire generation into despair about their country. Now that the national purpose has changed abroad, our domestic actions must seek to bring the young back into the political process.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: The continental shelf of Asia, running from waters off Burma to the seas between China and Japan, has become the focus of an in tense search for oil. More than 50 companies are drilling, doing geological studies or hold ing concessions. This activity has drawn the attention of some antiwar groups that have charged that the United States is fight ing in South Vietnam to protect oil industry interests. Thus far, most Congressmen appear to consider the charges unsubstantiated. The Saigon Government, however, is interested in attracting the oil industry to the area. On industry's side, preliminary seismic studies of offshore Vietnam have labeled it as geo logically “a good risk.” Only two countries in the entire area are producing oil in substan tial commercial quantities—Australia and In donesia. Indonesia, the center of most of the activity, is now producing about 900,000 bar‐ rels a day, almost entirely from onshore wells, but output is expected to climb to more than a million barrels a day this year, with the bulk of the addition coming from offshore wells. In the waters off Burma, Malaysia, Thailand and Cambodia, the activity is confined to surveys or preliminary drilling. Every Asian nation would like to find oil at home or at least nearby, and this quest has brought Japan, South Korea and Taiwan into con flict over jurisdiction and rights to grant con cessions in certain sections of the East China Sea. Communist China also is interested in oil in the area. United States awareness of this was demonstrated last week when it warned the Gulf Oil Corporation, which has an exploration contract with the Chinese Na tionalists, that it could not protect survey or drilling ships in the disputed areas around the Senkaku Islands.

headline: The Electoral Option in Vietnam: I

The massive numbers of antiwar demonstrators who gathered both San Francisco and the nation's capital over the weekend underscored the rising tide of disenchantment that sweeps now coast to coast, across much of American society.

headline: Secrecy on Ashau Drive
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, April 25—The joint United States and South Viet namese operation in the Ashau Valley area is 12 days old and still surrounded by official secrecy, leading some observers to wonder if something has gone wrong, or if the operation is just a training exercise for fresh Government troops.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Stratton for Shelving War Issue, But Women. Indicate Otherwise
lead_paragraph: ALBANY, April 25—Women members of the Democratic State Committee gave a cool reception, including some boos and hisses, tonight to Repre sentative Samuel S. Stratton's assertion that there is “very little difference” between Demo cratic and Republic positions on the Vietnam War.

headline: Agnew Disagrees but Cites Protesters for Orderliness
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (UPI) — Vice President Agnew said today that he strongly disagreed with the aim of yes terday's antiwar rally in Wash ington and found it “grotesque” that some of the demonstrators had carried Vietcong flags.

headline: Resor Arrives in Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25 (A11)— The Secretary of the Army, Stanley R. Resort arrived today to study the progress of Vietnamization and to look into the problem of drug addiction in the Army.

headline: Chou Attacks U.S. but on a Mild Note
lead_paragraph: PEKING, April 25—Premier Chou En‐lai struck a relatively mild note in a speech at a ban quet held here tonight to mark the first anniversary of the summit conference of Viet namese, Cambodian and Lao tian regimes at war with the United States and its allies in Indochina.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: AT HOME ABROAD
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 25 — In observance of Law Day, a group of New York law yers plan to march this Friday to Foley Square in lower Manhattan, there to speak about ending the war in Indo china. In several other cities commit tees of lawyers are working for an end to the war.
author: By Anthony Lewis

headline: Excerpts From Nixon Talk on Confidence
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)— Following are ex cerpts from the text of Presi dent Nixon's speech today to the United States Chamber of Commerce:

headline: U. S. Unaware of Turncoats
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26—A Pentagon spokesman said today the Defense Department had no knowledge of any American deserters fighting with the Viet cong in Vietnam.

headline: VIETCONG APPEAL TO G.I.'S TO DESERT
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 26 — The Viet cong today called on American soldiers in Vietnam to stop fighting or desert and added that some American soldiers were fighting in the Vietcong ranks.

headline: Flights Over Laos By Hanoi's MIG's Reported by U. S.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26— North Vietnamese MIG fighters have darted into southern Laos in the last few weeks “on sev eral occasions to threaten U.S. aircraft,” a Pentagon spokes man said today.

headline: Mao Said to Welcome a Nixon Visit
lead_paragraph: Chairman Mao Tse ‐ tung would welcome a visit from President Nixon and would be happy to talk with him, ac cording to Edgar Snow, the American writer who has had frequent access over the years to Chinese Communist officials.

headline: Agnew Calls Hoover's Critics Politically Motivated
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, April 26— Vice President Agnew strongly defended J. Edgar Hoover and the Federal Bureau of Investi gation here today in an 11 page, 28‐minute speech devoted entirely to the director, the agency and their critics.
author: BY Roy Reed Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Force in Vietnam Lowest Since July, 66
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP)—United States troop strength in South Viet nam dropped to 281,400 men last week, the United States command announced today. The total was 2,600 below the ceiling set by President Nixon for May 1 and represented the lowest level in nearly five years.

headline: TRIAL TOED KOTOUC MAIMED PRISONER
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 26—A former soldier testified today in the court‐martial of Army Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc that the stocky intelligence officer cut off the first joint of a finger of a Vietcong suspect he was questioning a few hours after the mass killings at the hamlet of Mylai three years ago.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: IN THE NATION
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26—The anti war demonstration here last week and those still to come suggested again how widespread is the opposition to continuing the war. But there is not yet a shred of evidence to suggest that this demonstrable opposition is causing the Nixon Administration to change its basic course.
author: By Tom Wicker

headline: PRESIDENT URGES BUSINESS TO SHUN ‘SENSE OF DESPAIR’
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26— President Nixon told an ap preciative audience of business men today that despite a “sense of despair” in some elements of the population, there was no reason to lose “confidence” in the nation's economy, the aims of its foreign policy, or its sense of concern for the poor.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘People's Lobby’ Begs for End of War
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 — Anti war protesters clad in bur lap sacks and smeared with make‐believe blood pleaded on Capitol Hill today for an end to the conflict in Vietnam.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: Munition Dump Destroyed As Foe Steps Up Attacks
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 27—A huge am munition dump in the side of a coastal mountain was exploded by enemy shelling early yester day, the third day of а wave of attacks through much of South Vietnam.

headline: Veterans Aide Cites Gains In Treating Drug Addicts
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) — Donald E. Johnson, Admin istrator of Veterans Affairs, testified today that good prog ress was being made in treat ing drug addicts among Viet nam war veterans who seek rehabilitation.

headline: U.S. Combat Deaths In Vietnam at 45,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26 (AP) — The number of American deaths in com bat in Vietnam has reached 45,000.

headline: 2 Ex‐Johnson Aides Back Warmaking‐Power Curbs
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 26 Two men who advised Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson on the Vietnam war today endorsed proposals to impose legislative restrictions on the President's power to commit the nation to War.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
lead_paragraph: CAPETOWN — Britain's equivalent of Vietnam was fought here in South Africa Seventy years ago. The cruel Boer War ruined the British reputa tion for international morality, lost the respect of foleign friends for considerable period, and stirred up hornet's nest of political opposition at home.
author: By C. L. Sulzberger

headline: Enemy Shells Bases 4th Consecutive Day
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 28 (AP)— Enemy gunners, taking advan tage of a period of moonless nights, staged small shelling at tacks against allied installa tions early yesterday for the fourth consecutive day.

headline: 33 Clerics Ask War Repentance Days
author: By Michael Knight

headline: Kotouc Cleared on One Charge But Maiming Accusation Stands
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 27 — The military judge in the Army court‐martial of Capt: Eugene M. Kotouc directed a verdict of acquittal today in one of two charges that the Government has brought against the stocky career officer.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Orders Ouster of Writer Who Reported on ‘ Tiger Cages’
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 27—The South Vietnamese Government has ordered Don Luce, a 36‐year‐old American writer, to leave the country before May 16.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Quest for Justice
lead_paragraph: In any society, the quest for justice is an endless and often frustrating journey. In the middle of a war being waged against a cruel, elusive enemy in an alien country, this quest takes on nightmarish qualities. Yet in Vietnam, as in other wars in the past, the American armed forces have to measure their conduct against this country's laws and ideals. No other standard would be either practical or morally tolerable.

headline: LAIRD SAYS SOVIET RENEWS ABM WORK
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27— Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that construc tion had resumed at one or more of four antimissile sites on the outskirts of Moscow aft er a break of about three years.be deploying multiple warheads on some large SS‐9 missiles was true.
author: By William Beecher Special to The New York Times

headline: Rival Banquet Protests Law Day Speech by U.S. Security Official
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27— Robert C. Mardian, the Justice Department”s chief internal security official, delivered to day the bar association's of ficial Law Day speech to 100 lawyers in a banquet room while three times as many law yers participated in a rival meeting in the adjoining room.
author: By Fred P. Graham Special to The New York Times

headline: War Foes Lobby, With Permission, at Capital Draft Headquarters
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)—Antiwar protesteri'but tonholed employes of the na tion's draft headquarters today with the blessing of the dirge tor. A few other demonstrators were arrested after spending the night in the office of Seno for Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the minority leader.

headline: ROGERS BIDS CHINA BE ‘CONSTRUCTIVE’ IN SOUTHEAST ASIA
lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 27—Secre tary of State William P. Rogers called on China today to begin to play a “constructive rather than disruptive role” in South east Asia.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: China and America: Beginnings
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.—The dramatic reversal in Sino‐American relations, is far more profound than mere Ping Pong diplomacy. Current contacts are actually increasingly semiofficial in nature.
author: By ISKWER C. OJHA and DANIEL TRETIAK

headline: RADICALS ASSAIL FULBRIGHT PANEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28— Representatives of a radical antiwar group accused the Sen ate Foreign Relations Commit tee today of a “lack of initia tive” in ending the Vietnam war and called Congress “the puppet of the madmen who are in power.”

headline: Laird Says Neutral Ships Would Evacuate P.O.W.'s
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28 (Reu ters)—Defense Secretary Mel vin R. Laird said today he had been assured that ships of neu tral nations were available to evacuate prisoners of both sides in the Vietnam war if Hanoi would agree to transfer prisoners to third countries.

headline: BAYH, IN TALK HERE, SCORES NIXON AGAIN
lead_paragraph: Senator Birch Bayh of Indi ana, one of several seeking con sideration for the Democratic nomination for President, at tacked President Nixon last night for criticizing “new isola tionists” in the United States without specifying whom he meant.

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28—One of the most difficult jobs in Government these days is held by Jim Dandy, Assistant Secretary of State for Balder dash and Guff, which are not, as the casual newspaper reader may suppose, obscure islands in the Arabian Sea, but highly spiced ingredients essential to a well‐cooked foreign policy.
author: By Russell Baker

headline: SOVIET ANALYZES ALLIES' LAOS PUSH
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 28— The Soviet Defense Ministry news paper, in an analysis of the recent Laotian operation, said today that the South Vietnam ese suffered heavy losses be cause American advisers un derestimated the opposing forces in the area and were caught by surprise by the in troduction of tanks and heavy artillery.
author: By Bernard Gwertzman Special to The New York Times

headline: Congressman Sees Deception in Ratio Of Noncombat Dead
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)—Representati William D. Ford has said that the mili tary's explanation of a recent rise of noncombat deaths in South Vietnam has not allayed his suspicions that the Penta gon is engaging in a “grisly numbers game” to hide hor rors of the war.

headline: Rogers Says U.S. Favors Exchanges Of Newsmen and Students With China
lead_paragraph: He also said a visit to main land China by President Nixon “might well be possible . . . down the road a piece” if re lations between Washington and Peking continued to im prove and China began to com ply with the rules of interna tional law.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: Ex‐G.I. Alleges 30 Slayings Near Mylai
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 28— A former Army sergeant said today that he took part in the killing of about 30 Vietnamese men, women, and children in a village called Truong Khanh, near Mylai, in April 1969.
author: By Richard Halloran Special to The New York Times

headline: KOTOUC DESCRIBES MAIMING INCIDENT
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 28—Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc took the witness stand today at his court‐martial and used the outstretched hand of his pros ecutor to demonstrate how he had chopped off the end of a prisoner's finger.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Ashau Sweep Continues
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 29 (AP) — An Americqn‐backed South Viet namese ground operation in the Ashau Valley area in the north ern quarter of the country en tered its third week yesterday. So far, however, no major con tact with the enemy has been reported.

headline: U.S. Jets Attack in North
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, April 29 (Reuters)—Two United States Navy F‐8 Crusader jets attacked North Vietnamese radar‐di rected antiaircraft sites 110 miles northwest of the demili tarized zone yesterdays the United States command an nounced today.

headline: S.L.A. Marshall: On the Nature of War
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Mich.—My attention has been drawn to an essay opposite your editorial page wherein Burke Marshall, acting as judge, jury and prosecutor, convicts all Americans of the crime at Mylai toward mitigating what was triggered by the direct ac tion of one lieutenant.
author: By S. L. A. Marshall

headline: HAMLETS WIPED OUT, EX‐MARINE TESTIFIES
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters)—A former marine corporal, Kenneth James Camp bell, said today that two North Vietnamese hamlets were wiped out in August, 1968, and their 30 civilian inhabitants killed by American artillery on the chance they may have been supplying rice to Communist troops.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Frank Masland

headline: Cambodians and Enemy Clash Again in Hand‐to‐Hand Battles
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, April 29 (AP)—Cambodian troops fought hand‐to‐hand battles with enemy soldiers today for the second consecutive day on Route 4, Pnompenh's supply route from the sea, the high command said.

headline: PENTAGON DENIES A NUMBERS GAME
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— The Defense Department said today that while combat casual ties in Vietnam declined 70 per cent between 1968 and 1970, noncombat casualties had re mained almost constant.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: Article 2 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 29—A spokes man for the Communist‐led pro visional Revolutionary Govern ment said today that the kill ings described by Mr. Notley in Washington had been broad er in scope than the witness realized.

headline: Ford Assails Muskie and Fulbright Stands on Mideast
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— Before a gathering of Jewish leaders, Representative Gerald R. Ford, the House Republican leader, today accused Senator Edmund S. Muskie and Senator J. W. Fulbright of undermining American support of Israel.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: NIXON INDICATES INDEFINITE STAY FOR VIETNAM G.I.'S
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29— President Nixon said tonight that a residual force of United States troops would remain in South Vietnam indefinitely— “no matter how long it takes” —if Hanoi refused to release American prisoners of war.
author: By Robert B. Semple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: PEACE TOUR SET BY CONGRESSMEN
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 29 — More than 20 members of Con gress have agreed to travel around the country in a new antiwar program designed to bring constituent pressure on Senators and Congressmen re luctant to push for an early withdrawal of American forces from Vietnam.
author: By R. W. Apple Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Kotouc Is Acquitted of Maiming A Vietnamese Prisoner at Mylai
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, April 29—An Army court‐martial jury cleared Capt. Eugene M. Kotouc of guilt today in the maiming of a Vietnamese prisoner three years ago at Mylai 4, an act the officer said he had com mitted by accident.
author: By Jon Nordheimer Special to The New York Times

headline: Hanoi Asks U.S. to Open Talks Now on Pullout Date
lead_paragraph: PARIS, April 29—North Viet nam invited the United States today to open negotiations “this very day, or tomorrow, or another day” on setting a date for the withdrawal of all Amer ican troops from South Viet nam.
author: By John L. Hess Special to The New York Times

headline: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of Presi dent Nixon's news conference last night as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Sylvia R. Day

headline: Hanoi Reports a Prisoner Denies Capture of Tchepone
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, April 29 (Reu ters)—A captured South Viet namese officer was quoted today by the North Vietnam news agency as saying that Saigon troops never reached the strategic town of Tchepone during last month's strike against the Ho Chi Minh Trail in southern Laos.

headline: Another Way the U.S. Has Left Its Mark on Vietnam
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 — Although she is only 4 years old, Nina Deng remembers the day her fa ther, a United States Navy chief petty officer, went back to the states and his American wife. Her mother, Dang Thi Hoa, carried her to the door and tearfully waved good‐by. Her father cried, too. He kissed them and prom ised to write every week.

headline: 45 Killed in Week; American War Toll Now Over 45,000
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Ap ril 29 (UPI) — The United States command announced to day that 45 Americans died in combat last week in Indochina, raising the total in the war since the beginning of 1961 past the 45,000 mark.

headline: Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 29 (AP)—United States B‐52 bombers struck at targets in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam today in another intensive effort to force North Vietnamese troops from jungle bases, the United States com mand said.
